hints_html:
To incorporate the initial value \(\displaystyle y(0) = \begin{bmatrix}-1 \\1\end{bmatrix}\), the constants \(\displaystyle C_1,C_2\) must be chosen such that (from part (b)):

\(y(t) = C_1 e^t\begin{bmatrix} \cos(2t) \\ \cos(2t)+\sin(2t) \end{bmatrix} + C_2 e^t\begin{bmatrix} \sin(2t) \\ \sin(2t) - \cos(2t) \end{bmatrix}\)

holds for \(\displaystyle t=0\)
hints_latex:
To incorporate the initial value
$\displaystyle y(0) = \begin{bmatrix}-1 \\1\end{bmatrix}$, the constants
$\displaystyle C_1,C_2$ must be chosen such that (from
{part
(b)}):

$y(t) = C_1 e^t\begin{bmatrix} \cos(2t) \\ \cos(2t)+\sin(2t) \end{bmatrix} + C_2 e^t\begin{bmatrix}  \sin(2t) \\  \sin(2t) - \cos(2t) \end{bmatrix}$

holds for $\displaystyle t=0$
hints_raw:
To incorporate the initial value <math> \displaystyle y(0) = \begin{bmatrix}-1 \\1\end{bmatrix} </math>, the constants <math> \displaystyle C_1,C_2</math> must be chosen such that (from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2013/Question_B_06_(b)|part (b)]]):

<math>
y(t) = C_1 e^t\begin{bmatrix} \cos(2t) \\ \cos(2t)+\sin(2t) \end{bmatrix} + C_2 e^t\begin{bmatrix}  \sin(2t) \\  \sin(2t) - \cos(2t) \end{bmatrix}
</math>

holds for <math>\displaystyle t=0</math>
question: B 06 (c)
sols_html:
Using the solution from part (b),

\(y(t) = C_1 e^t\begin{bmatrix} \cos(2t) \\ \cos(2t)+\sin(2t) \end{bmatrix} + C_2 e^t\begin{bmatrix} \sin(2t) \\ \sin(2t) - \cos(2t) \end{bmatrix}\)

we have for \(\displaystyle t=0\)

\(y(0) = C_1 \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1\end{bmatrix} + C_2\begin{bmatrix} 0\\-1\end{bmatrix}\)

Because the given intial values are \(\displaystyle y(0) = \begin{bmatrix}-1\\1\end{bmatrix}\), we write

\(\begin{bmatrix}-1\\1\end{bmatrix} = C_1 \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1\end{bmatrix} + C_2\begin{bmatrix} 0\\-1\end{bmatrix}\)

This is

\[\begin{aligned} -1 &= C_1 \\ 1 &= C_1-C_2\end{aligned}\]

and \(\displaystyle C_1 = -1\) and \(\displaystyle C_2 = -2\). Hence, the solution is

\[\begin{aligned} y(t) &= -e^t\begin{bmatrix} \cos(2t) \\ \cos(2t)+\sin(2t) \end{bmatrix} - 2 e^t\begin{bmatrix} \sin(2t) \\ \sin(2t) - \cos(2t) \end{bmatrix}\\ &= e^t\begin{bmatrix} -2\sin(2t) - \cos(2t) \\ -3\sin(2t) +\cos(2t)\end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
Using the solution from
{part
(b)},

$y(t) = C_1 e^t\begin{bmatrix} \cos(2t) \\ \cos(2t)+\sin(2t) \end{bmatrix} + C_2 e^t\begin{bmatrix}  \sin(2t) \\  \sin(2t) - \cos(2t) \end{bmatrix}$

we have for $\displaystyle t=0$

$y(0) = C_1 \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1\end{bmatrix} + C_2\begin{bmatrix} 0\\-1\end{bmatrix}$

Because the given intial values are
$\displaystyle y(0) = \begin{bmatrix}-1\\1\end{bmatrix}$, we write

$\begin{bmatrix}-1\\1\end{bmatrix} = C_1 \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1\end{bmatrix} + C_2\begin{bmatrix} 0\\-1\end{bmatrix}$

This is

\begin{align*}
-1 &= C_1 \\ 
1 &= C_1-C_2
\end{align*}

and $\displaystyle C_1 = -1$ and $\displaystyle C_2 = -2$. Hence, the
solution is

\begin{align*}
y(t) &=  -e^t\begin{bmatrix} \cos(2t) \\ \cos(2t)+\sin(2t) \end{bmatrix} - 2 e^t\begin{bmatrix}  \sin(2t) \\  \sin(2t) - \cos(2t) \end{bmatrix}\\
&= e^t\begin{bmatrix} -2\sin(2t) - \cos(2t) \\ -3\sin(2t) +\cos(2t)\end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
Using the solution from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2013/Question_B_06_(b)|part (b)]],

<math>
y(t) = C_1 e^t\begin{bmatrix} \cos(2t) \\ \cos(2t)+\sin(2t) \end{bmatrix} + C_2 e^t\begin{bmatrix}  \sin(2t) \\  \sin(2t) - \cos(2t) \end{bmatrix}
</math>

we have for <math>\displaystyle t=0</math> 

<math>
y(0) = C_1 \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1\end{bmatrix} + C_2\begin{bmatrix} 0\\-1\end{bmatrix}
</math>

Because the given intial values are <math>\displaystyle y(0) = \begin{bmatrix}-1\\1\end{bmatrix}</math>, we write

<math>
\begin{bmatrix}-1\\1\end{bmatrix} = C_1 \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1\end{bmatrix} + C_2\begin{bmatrix} 0\\-1\end{bmatrix}
</math>

This is

<math>\begin{align}
 -1 &= C_1 \\ 
1 &= C_1-C_2
\end{align}</math>

and <math>\displaystyle C_1 = -1 </math> and <math>\displaystyle  C_2 = -2</math>. Hence, the solution is

<math>\begin{align}
y(t) &=  -e^t\begin{bmatrix} \cos(2t) \\ \cos(2t)+\sin(2t) \end{bmatrix} - 2 e^t\begin{bmatrix}  \sin(2t) \\  \sin(2t) - \cos(2t) \end{bmatrix}\\
&= e^t\begin{bmatrix} -2\sin(2t) - \cos(2t) \\ -3\sin(2t) +\cos(2t)\end{bmatrix}
\end{align}</math>
statement_html:
Consider the system of linear differential equations given by

\[\begin{aligned} y'_{1}(t) &= 3y_{1}(t) - 2y_{2}(t)\\ y'_{2}(t) &= 4y_{1}(t) - y_{2}(t)\end{aligned}\]

Find the solution of the system of linear differential equations above with the initial condition \(y(0) = \begin{bmatrix} -1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\)
statement_latex:
Consider the system of linear differential equations given by

\begin{align*}
y'_{1}(t) &= 3y_{1}(t) - 2y_{2}(t)\\
y'_{2}(t) &= 4y_{1}(t) - y_{2}(t)
\end{align*}

Find the solution of the system of linear differential equations above
with the initial condition
$y(0) = \begin{bmatrix} -1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$
statement_raw:
Consider the system of linear differential equations given by 

<math>
\begin{align}
y'_{1}(t) &= 3y_{1}(t) - 2y_{2}(t)\\
y'_{2}(t) &= 4y_{1}(t) - y_{2}(t)
\end{align}
</math>

Find the solution of the system of linear differential equations above with the initial condition <math>y(0) = \begin{bmatrix} -1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} </math>
